I think thou wast born under some merry planet, in the time of diversity.

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ Now sith Victoria's name is like for ever to be lost,
Further revenge I will not seek, as I to her did boast.
Because that as myself unjustly served Virginia.
So am I now justly requited by Victoria.
Therefore Pedante go, and pardon of Virginia crave,
And tell her that I will be hers,

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ That's it she would have.
But I beseech you sir, tarry till the day be light,
I am loath to go stumbling in the streets this night,

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ Then till the morning let it rest, but early see thou rise,
And do my message in the meekest sort thou canst devise.
Mean while we'll home and take a sleep,Exit with them that held the net.for I am overwatched.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ Very well sir, bear you the net after,
I have some business with the captain to be dispatched.
Now master captain come with me, for as soon as my master to bed I have brought,
You shall see what a thing for you I have wrought.
And because you have determined on Victoria to revenge your wrong,
It must be done this night or never, time do not prolong.
As her flattery this night, bring did you in bands,
So this night I shall deliver her into your hands.

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ Then let us away and ourselves provide,
Thou knowest the proverb, nobody tarries for the tide. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The fourth act being ended, the consort soundeth a pleasant Allemaigne.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Fortunio alone.
div.l: I know Virginia loves Fedele best,
Medusa likewise may be sent to flout:
Myself her favour never yet possessed,
If none of these, yet all may make me doubt.
How service should with bright triumphing face,
Disperse the clouds, that put my joys to chase.
Yet if Fedele be not liked alone,
Or if Medusa of true promise be:
Or fair Virginia will be moved by moan.
If not all these, yet one may pleasure me.
Therefore, to give the watch word I'll begin,Whistle.
Good luck, the door opens, I'll enter in. Exit.
div.stage: Enter Atilia.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ Take heed Attilia, was not that Fortunio thou didst see?
'Tis now midnight, so late abroad i'th street what maketh he?
I see Pedante is not here, I muse he meets me not,
I little thought he could so soon his promise have forgotten.
If he be master of his word, and love me as his life,
The time is come to show the same, and take me for his wife.

div.head: Actus quinta. Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Pedante and Crack-stone with the beggar's weed.
div.l: Come on sir apace, what makes you so slack?
Presently put me this robe on your back.
Now get you up along the street, and be not afraid,
There shall you meet Victoria, in the apparel of her maid.
Thinking you thus disguised, to be Fortunio,
Very ready you shall find her with you to go.
When you have her, hold fast, for she will not resist,
Woe her, wed her, bed her, and use her as you list.
Either now or never, your desire you shall have,
Or be revenged on the entertainment that out of her window to you she gave.

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ See the force of love, how it is able for a need,
To shroud a brave mind in a base kind of weed.
Master Pediculus, or Pedantonie, I am not very prospect in your name,
If this gear fall out, I shall be bound while I live, to thank you for the same.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ I would not be he that should so courageous a captain, and valiant gentleman deceive.
Therefore try me, and trust me, for this time I purpose to take my leave

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ Farewell little pastry,Exit.if I may meet with mistress Victoriarie here.
Thinking that Fortunio in this place, to her will appear.
Either I will make her incant the former words that she spoke,
When she defied me, and denied that she willed me to kill Fedele for her sake.
Or I will back beat her, and belly beat her too too pitifully,
You know love is a fire, and they say fire and water hath no mercy.
But first I will speak her fair, because to be plain,
Commonly fair fools make words and persuasions to be fain.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ Alas how long in the street shall I for my Pedante stay?
He promised to meet me here, and steal me quite away.
Somebody in the street I hear, I trust the same is he,
And so I do persuade me, by the beggar's weed I see.

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ I'll believe Pediculus again another day,
For yonder in Alice tittle tattles 'parel the mistress doth stay,
Oh that I had some of Pediculus' school-butter to make me a lip salve,
Or could but wet my tongue in his inkhorn, for women will harken when we speak brave.
O thou that carriest a ball of wild fire in thine eye, to burn up my heart,
What shall I say more, to set out my smart.
The time will not suffer to show my prosperity,
therefore I commit you to the gods for lack of brevity.

div.head: Actus quinta. Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Sbirri the captain of the watch, with some soldiers, and with him mistress Victoria.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ See how Pedante counterfeits Crack-stone in talk,
Thereby we shall escape, and through the watch in safety walk.

sp.speaker: Victoria.
sp.l: ¶ Captain Sbirri, this night my maid Attilia ran away,
Her I beseech you, if she be not passed the watch, to stay.
Some thing I doubt that she hath stolen, and carried to her mates,
Therefore I pray beset the streets, and all the city gates.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Mistress Victoria I will, but somebody I see,

sp.speaker: Victoria.
sp.l: ¶ Step to them both and take them straight, for sure the same is she.

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ Come mine own paragon, I know thou hast tarried for me all this while,
Therefore follow me straight, lest the liquorish soldiers meet us, and me beguile.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Soft not to fast, but stay I charge you in the prince's name,

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ God save the prince's grace, and put his enemies to shame.
We are the King's friends, I would you should well know,
Therefore trouble us no farther, but let us go.
The King's head is occupied with matters of great importunity,
I know he is not conswapted, at this time to speak with me.
We are peaceable people, we have no weapons here,
We are neither drunk nor sober, nor make any steer.
Get you to your places, keep the watch as you should,
And we'll to our lodging you may be bold.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Nay sir, we will know your name, and eke the place where you have been,
whether you go, night-walkers here are very seldom seen.

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ Then I pray you, what make you abroad so late?
'Tis longing to your office to keep the gate.
As for our names, I know of no such commencement you have,
Why you should be so perceant the same to crave.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ We have been forth at supper sir, i'the town with a good friend,
And now we are returning home, nigh at our journey's end.

sp.speaker: Victoria.
sp.l: ¶ What minion, are you there indeed?

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ My mistress, out alas,
Behold Pedante we are ta'en, how shall we do to pass?

sp.speaker: Crack-st,
sp.l: ¶ I hold forty pound I am uncled, I would Pediculus were here,
I would meet with the scald squitterbe-booke for this gear.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Is this your maid?

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ It is.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Lay hold on her with speed,
Let us see what vagabond is hid within this weed.
Crack-stone? Whowe?

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ And whowe too then, did you never see man before?
I am not taken in devoutry, therefore wonder no more.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ A halter come to him, is it he?

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Sorry I am good captain, you in such a case to see.
Here you are taken with this maid, which is like to be taught
Of felony, and accessary you with her are caught.

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ I steal nothing from women but their honesty:
Which is as good, as he that robs the printer of a bible, because he would study divinity.

div.head: Actus quinta. Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Fortunio running half unready, after him Ottaviano the father to mistress Virginia, and Medusa with a spit in her hand, and to them Fedele and Pedante, with weapons in their hands.

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ Stop, stop.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ What meaneth this? come bend your weapons at them all,
Whom shall we stop? and what's the cause that makes you thus to call?

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ Pedante, take thy sword,Fedele and Pedante speak out at a window within.arise let's go into the street,
some wondrous broil I doubt there is,

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ I am so fast wrapped in the upper sheet.
That I can not get out, I pray you make not such haste,
Till you think that the hottest of the broil be past.

sp.speaker: Fortunio ▪
sp.l: ¶ Stay captain, lay no hands on me, a gentleman I am,
And will not flit,

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ Woe worth the time that to my house he came.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Ottaviano, what's the cause of your lamenting cry?
Let's know, hath sir Fortunio done you any injury?

div.stage: Enter Fedele and Pedante with weapons.

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ Come quickly man, let's see this pageant ere it take an end,

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ He that breaks me of my sleep, is none of my friend,

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: ¶ Ah wretch that am I alas, and half undone,

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ What strange kind of broil is this that is begun?

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ Is it Fortunio in deed? This is thy treachery, Medusa.

sp.speaker: Medusa.
sp.l: ¶ Mine, alas good sir, you do me injury,
I grant that after I had brought my young mistress to bed,
Feeling the sleep shut up mine eyes, and drooping with my head,
I laid me down to take my rest, and so with haste forgotten,
To lock the doors about the house, and how it comes God wot,
I can not tell, but when I fetched a nap and woke again,
I heard a bustling in the dark, and then did I complain.
And cried aloud to you for help, whereat immediately,
This gentleman withdrew himself, and forth began to fly.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ Master.

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ Your cake is dough,

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ It kills me to think on it: the greater my woe.

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ This is luck nidget with all my heart,
¶ I am glad, that I have somebody to take my part.
But o that my hands were at liberality now to strike,
I would set my gramariner a lesson to pike.

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ Ah sir Fortunio, use you thus the man that loved you best,
Take him, this villainy shall not be turned to a jest.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Quiet yourself Ottaviano, sith it is so past,
The brute will not be called back so long as life doth last.
His punishment makes not your daughter as she was before,
but give her unto him to wife, and talk of it no more.
His living is as good as yours, make up the match with speed,

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ Need hath no law, I am content, if they be both agreed.

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: ¶ Alas I never knew the man, he never touched me yet,
I love Fedele, and he alone is for Virginia fit?

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ I'll take no wife at second hand, thanks for your courtesy,
Let him that hath possessed your honour, wear the same for me.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ In every tennis court in the world, false play it is found,
To take up the ball at the second rebound.

sp.speaker: Fortunio.
sp.l: ¶ Virginia, if that you can be content,
To like of him that loves you in his heart:
Give me your hand, and if your mind be bent,
To marry me, I never mean to part.
My life, and living, more you can not crave,
Remaineth yours, do now but ask and have.

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: ¶ I thank you sir, in that it pleaseth you to use me so,
My promise was nigh granted to Fedele long ago.

sp.speaker: Fortunio.
sp.l: ¶ But he hath now forsaken you.

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ Virginia, you are free,
Assure yourself, your marriage never shall be stayed by me.

sp.speaker: Virginia.
sp.l: ¶ Then if you love I will be yours.

sp.speaker: Fortunio.
sp.l: ¶ Shall I have your good will?

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ You have.

sp.speaker: Fortunio.
sp.l: ¶ I love you then, and mean to love you still.

sp.speaker: Medusa.
sp.l: ¶ Now man and wife, Ottaviano harken unto me,
Although this gallant in Virginia's chamber you did see.
Yet is her honour as it was, unspotted by the same,
And kept by me, which ever had regard unto her name.
Fortunio made his moan and said, he loved Virginia best,
Virginia for Fedele's sake could never take her rest.
His mind was on Victoria, Virginia light esteemed,
Now that Virginia's life and liberty might be redéemded.
I brought Fortunio to the house when she was fast a sleep,
And close this night into her chamber both of us did creep.
I made him to unbrace himself, and presently did call
For you to come, as though some greater matter did befall.
You came, he fled, and now is taken in Fedele's sight,
As though Virginia had dishonoured been by him this night.
Which is not so, but this was done to blear the gazer's eyes,
To pleasure him, and save her life, this thing did I devise.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ O mischievous head, master did you hear this gear,
Such a girl is worth gold in a dear year.

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ I ipse tipse, tittle, tittle este amen,
Such a wench is not be found in the world again.
I have heard it often, and now I do prove,
That women are subtle worms for the convariance of love.

sp.speaker: Ottaui.
sp.l: ¶ If this be true I joy?

sp.speaker: Fortunio.
sp.l: ¶ Else take my head,
I came not nigh Virginia, although she were in bed.

sp.speaker: Fedele.
sp.l: ¶ Fortunio you are quit with me, for when we lay in scout,
To watch by fair Victoria's house, who passed in and out.
It was my man disguised, that issued forth out of the same,
That for the nonce by me was set, to call Victoria by her name.
He went unto Attilia, with counterfeited love,
That by his means, from fair Victoria I might you remove.
You seeing him, and hearing when he came forth, what he said,
Thought he had been with her, when he had been but with the maid.
Whereat you stormed, and left the chase of her that loved you dear,
Which is no grief at all to me, that hopes to win her here.
Therefore Victoria now forget Fortunio which is lost,
And love Fedele, who for you, yet never spared cost.
Let fall thy wrath, for give me too, that means to be thine own,
'Tis seldom seen but wars have end, when foes are overthrown.

sp.speaker: Victoria.
sp.l: ¶ Sith you have so prevented me, and perfect love protest,
I will put up the injury, and yours for ever rest.

sp.speaker: Crack-st,
sp.l: ¶ My nose is jointed, I may go shoe the gosling now if I will,
He that eats with thedevil without a long spoon, his fare will be ill.
What spirits of the buttery were abroad this night,
I have been so hard hearted to mine enemies, that I think all the gods of love ought me a spite.
I grant I am none of these fine criminadoes, that can tumble in a gentlewoman's lap, and rumble in her ear,
But without vantage be it spoken, I am as góod as the best at the push of a spear.
I can cut and flash to make mine enemies to bleed.
And prick it proudly I tell you, when I am surmounted upon my steed.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Mistress Victoria, now I see this only rests to know,
What shall be done unto your maid, or shall we let her go?

sp.speaker: Victoria.
sp.l: ¶ Sith with Crack-stone this night, you took my maid so short,
To prison with her if you please, to cut off her resort.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ Good mistress bear with me, I took no hurt by him at all,
But mean to tell you justly how the matter did befall.
The schoolmaster that on Fedele ever doth attend,
Promised to marry me this night, my servile life to end.
Upon whose word, from you I fled, and stayed for him in the street
Where I against my will, with this Crack-stone did meet.

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ Bowl to thy bias, master Pediculus, I pray you take your wife,
You and I for this matter will not stand at strife.
Are you remembered what you said when you consulted with me,
To come hither in this 'parel secretly.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ What master Crack-stone, and mistress Attilia, you are welcome to the butts,

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ Welcome with a knave's name, I beshrumpe your guts.

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ Why so sir?

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ Didst not thou tell me, that in this 'parel mistress Victoria I should see.
This night in the street to be compensed of my injury,

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ So you may if you please, take your eyes in your hand,
Turn about sir, and see where Victoria doth stand.
And as for Attilia, as you brew, so bake,
I am not so base minded your leavings to take.

sp.speaker: Attilia.
sp.l: ¶ Why master Pedante, will you serve me so?

sp.speaker: Pedante.
sp.l: ¶ I must I perceive whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Crack-st.
sp.l: ¶ Draw villain.

sp.speaker: Sbirri.
sp.l: ¶ Soft there Crack-stone, be not too rash to proffer fight,
You and this maid together in the dark were ta'en this night.
The matter is suspicious, sith he forsaketh her,
To take her to your wife no time you should defer.
We cannot force her upon him, sith she was ta'en with you.
And howsoever you cloak it, none your meeting can allow.

sp.speaker: Crack-st
sp.l: ¶ Well sith there is no remorse of conscience to be found,
How sayest thou Alice tittle tattle, art thou content by love to be bound?

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
